Commutative Property

The commutative property states that the numbers on which we operate can be moved or swapped from their position without making any difference to the answer. The property holds for Addition and Multiplication, but not for subtraction and division. 

Addition
Subtraction
Multiplication
Division

 

The above examples clearly show that we can apply the commutative property on addition and multiplication. However, we cannot apply commutative property on subtraction and division. If you move the position of numbers in subtraction or division, it changes the entire problem. 

Therefore, if a and b are two non-zero numbers, then:

The commutative property of addition is:

            a + b = b + a

 The commutative property of multiplication is:

            a × b = b × a

In short, in commutative property, the numbers can be added or multiplied to each other in any order without changing the answer.

 

Let us see some examples to understand commutative property.

Example 1: Commutative property with addition

Myra has 5 marbles, and Rick has 3 marbles. How many marbles they have in total?

To find the answer, we need to add 5 and 3. 

 

Hence, we can see whether we add 5 + 3 or 3 + 5, the answer is always 8.

 

Example 2:  Commutative property with subtraction.

Alvin has 12 apples. He gives 8 apples to his sister. How many apples are left with Alvin?

Here, we subtract 8 from 12 and get the answer as 4 apples. However, we cannot subtract 12 from 8 and get 8 as the answer. 

 

Example 3: Commutative property with multiplication.

Sara buys 3 packs of buns. Each pack has 4 buns. How many buns did she buy?

Here, if we multiply 3 by 4 or 4 by 3, in both cases we get the answer as 12 buns.

So, the commutative property holds for multiplication.

So, commutative property holds true for multiplication.

 

Example 4: Commutative property with division.

If you have to divide 25 strawberries to 5 kids, each kid will receive 5 strawberries. However, if you have to divide 5 strawberries amongst 25 children, every kid will get a tiny fraction of the strawberry. Therefore, we cannot apply the commutative property with the division.

 

 

≠

  Fun fact:

  • Commutative property gets its name from the word commutes, meaning move around.

Grade 2 Math Curriculum

  • Place Value

    • 1. Represent 3 Digit Numbers
    • 2. Understanding Place Value
    • 3. Expanded Forms

  • Number Sense

    • 1. Count by 2's
    • 2. Count by 5's
    • 3. Count by 10's
    • 4. Count by 100's
    • 5. Even and Odd Numbers
    • 6. Compare Numbers upto 1000
    • 7. Order Numbers upto 1000

  • Add within 20

    • 1. Addition Sentences
    • 2. Add Two Numbers
    • 3. Add Three Numbers
    • 4. Addition Word Problems within 20

  • Subtract within 20

    • 1. Relate Addition and Subtraction
    • 2. Count Back to Subtract
    • 3. Subtract
    • 4. Fact Families
    • 5. Subtraction Word Problems within 20

  • Add within 100

    • 1. 2 Digit + 1 Digit
    • 2. 2 Digit + 2 Digit
    • 3. 2 Digit + 1 Digit with Regrouping
    • 4. 2 Digit + 2 Digit with Regrouping
    • 5. Addition Word Problems within 100

  • Subtract within 100

    • 1. Subtract Tens from a 2 Digit Number
    • 2. 2 Digit - 1 Digit
    • 3. 2 Digit - 2 Digit
    • 4. 2 Digit - 1 Digit with Regrouping
    • 5. 2 Digit - 2 Digit with Regrouping
    • 6. Subtraction Word Problems within 100

  • Add within 1000

    • 1. Add Multiples of 100
    • 2. Add 10 or 100 to a 3 Digit Number
    • 3. 3 Digit + 1 Digit
    • 4. 3 Digit + 2 Digit
    • 5. 3 Digit + 3 Digit
    • 6. Add by Composing Tens
    • 7. Add by Composing Hundreds
    • 8. Add by Composing Tens and Hundreds
    • 9. Addition Word Problems within 1000

  • Subtract within 1000

    • 1. Subtract Multiples of 100
    • 2. Subtract 10 or 100
    • 3. 3 Digit - 1 Digit
    • 4. 3 Digit - 2 Digit
    • 5. 3 Digit - 3 Digit
    • 6. Subtract by Breaking up Tens
    • 7. Subtract by Breaking up Hundreds
    • 8. Subtract by Breaking up Tens and Hundreds
    • 9. Subtraction Word Problems within 1000

  • Time

    • 1. Tell time to Quarter Hours
    • 2. Tell time to 5 Minutes
    • 3. Tell Time Using a.m. and p.m.

  • Money

    • 1. Penny, Nickel and Dime
    • 2. Value of coins
    • 3. Count Money
    • 4. Quarter and Half Dollar
    • 5. Counting with Quarters and Half Dollars
    • 6. Compare Amounts
    • 7. Make Amounts
    • 8. Add and Subtract Money
    • 9. Making Change

  • Measurements

    • 1. Estimate Length - Metric Units
    • 2. Measure Length - Metric Units
    • 3. Estimate Length - Customary Units
    • 4. Measure Length - Customary Units

  • Data

    • 1. Read Data from Line Plots
    • 2. Represent Data on a Line Plot
    • 3. Read Data from Picture Graphs
    • 4. Represent Data on Picture Graphs
    • 5. Read Data from Bar Graphs
    • 6. Represent Data on a Bar Graph

  • Geometry

    • 1. Two Dimensional Shapes
    • 2. Partition shapes
